00001 #include <iostream>
00002 #include "threadpool.h"
00003 
00004 using namespace std;
00005 
00006 
00007 #define ITERATIONS 100
00008 
00009 class SampleWorkerThread : public WorkerThread
00010 {
00011 public:
00012         unsigned virtual executeThis()
00013         {
00014         // Instead of sleep() we could do anytime consuming work here.
00015         //Using ThreadPools is advantageous only when the work to be done is really time consuming. (atleast 1 or 2 seconds)
00016                 sleep(2);
00017 
00018                 return(0);
00019         }
00020 };
00021 
00022 
00023 int main(int argc, char **argv)
00024 {
00025     ThreadPool tp;
00026 
00027         //ThreadPool(N);
00028         //Create a Threadpool with N number of threads
00029         ThreadPool* myPool = new ThreadPool(10);
00030         myPool->initializeThreads();
00031 
00032         //We will count time elapsed after initializeThreads()
00033     time_t t1=time(NULL);
00034 
00035         //Lets start bullying ThreadPool with tonnes of work !!!
00036         for(unsigned int i=0;i<ITERATIONS;i++){
00037                 SampleWorkerThread* myThread = new SampleWorkerThread();
00038                 myPool->assignWork(myThread);
00039         }
00040         
00041         // destroyPool(int maxPollSecs)
00042         // Before actually destroying the ThreadPool, this function checks if all the pending work is completed.
00043         // If the work is still not done, then it will check again after maxPollSecs
00044         // The default value for maxPollSecs is 5 seconds.
00045         // And ofcourse the user is supposed to adjust it for his needs.
00046     myPool->destroyPool(2);
00047         
00048     time_t t2=time(NULL);
00049     printf("%d seconds elapsed\n", t2-t1);
00050         delete myPool;
00051         
00052     return 0;
00053 }
